page.title: 03Ecology of the Downs 2
page.content: Beachy Head marks the starting point of the chalk hills - the South Downs - which stretch westward away from Eastbourne. The Downs are covered with a thin layer of soil between 6 & 12 inches in depth and occasionally with clay to a greater depth. This chalk has, in the past, been a source of flint used for both building and tools. The chalk cliffs that form the shore-line are receding at the rate of 30-40cms a year on average. The cliffs do not recede gradually but large chunks fall away after storms about 2 or 3 times a year. The most abundant animal now living on the Downs is the rabbit, which burrows throughout the topsoil and also keeps down the level of plants; there are also badgers and weasels, while birds include kestrels, barn owls and sky-larks.
